He is due to serve in the position until 2020. (japantimes.co.jp, 04 Sep 2017) "), ('Relatives', "His wife Kana Abe represented Japan in judo, winning gold in the women's team competition at the 2013 World Championships in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. His older brother Satoru was also a judoka, and has worked as coach at the Park 24 club in Japan. (SportsDeskOnline, 18 Jun 2018; judo.park24.co.jp, 28 May 2018; hochi.co.jp, 10 Feb 2016)"), ('Injuries', "In 2015 he sustained injuries to his left shoulder. (sponichi.co.jp, 08 Feb 2016) He was injured in the final of the 2013 World Championships in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, when he refused to submit to his opponent's ude-garami. He continued the match to win gold. (insidethegames.biz, 27 Aug 2013)In February 2012 he fractured the xiphoid process on the lower part of his sternum and could not train properly for a month. name: Takuya
bio: [('Beginning', 'He took up the sport at age nine. (hanedatakuya.com, 14 Apr 2014)'), ('Reason', 'He was influenced by his father and his older brother. (hanedatakuya.com, 14 Apr 2014; rowingone.com, 10 Mar 2010)'), ('Coach', 'Milan Kuban [national], SVK; Shuji Yamanaka [national], JPN (sankei.com, 02 Jan 2018; city.hagi.lg.jp, 15 Jan 2018)'), ('Training', 'His training sessions include cross-country skiing. (city.tokamachi.lg.jp, 09 Feb 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win gold at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (hanedatakuya.com, 20 Sep 2015; sports.mikihouse.co.jp, 19 Aug 2015)'), ('Awards', 'He received a Special Achievement Award at the 2016 Japanese Olympic Committee [JOC] Sports Awards. (joc.or.jp, 2016)In 2016 he was presented with the Kandou Grand Award by the governor of Osaka-fu in Japan. (sankei.com, 11 Jan 2017)In 2016 he was given the Toyota City Sports Honorary Award in Japan. (city.toyota.aichi.jp, 29 Aug 2016)In 2014 he received the Aichi Prefecture Sport Achievement Award in Japan. (aichi.jp, 14 Jan 2015)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTHe became the first Japanese slalom paddler to win a medal at the Olympic Games by finishing third in the C1 at the 2016 Games in Rio de Janeiro. (SportsDeskOnline, 01 Jun 2018; ktv.jp, 28 Oct 2016)TRAINING MOVEAfter finishing high school in April 2006, he moved to Slovakia to train with European athletes and take advantage of the facilities there. He combined his training with studying at Comenius University in Bratislava. (aitai.ne.jp, 01 Jan 2015; hanedatakuya.com, 14 Apr 2014; koseijp.co.jp, 04 Oct 2007) '), ('Hero', 'Slovak slalom paddler Michal Martikan. (tfm.co.jp, 18 Dec 2016)'), ('Influence', 'His father. name: RYOSUKE
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began swimming at age four in Osaka, Japan. (ar-services.jp, 08 May 2014)'), ('Reason', 'He followed his older brother Shinpei into the sport, but initially did not like swimming. His mother promised if he still did not enjoy it after a year she would ask the coach if he could quit. However, she forgot to honour her promise. "I only had negative feelings toward swimming. I really hated it, and wasn\'t very good at it either. I am what I am today because my mother didn\'t ask my coach to let me quit." (ajw.asahi.com, 11 Jul 2012)'), ('Debut', '2006 for Japan, Pan Pacific Championships in Victoria, Canada (tobiuojapan.org, 24 Jun 2015)'), ('Coach', 'Norimasa Hirai [national], JPN (swim.or.jp, 01 Oct 2017)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. name: SEIJI
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began paddling at age 13 in Miyagi Prefecture, Japan. (cyclestyle.net, 30 Jun 2015; ninomiyasports.com, 01 May 2013)'), ('Reason', 'There was a canoe team at his middle school. (cyclestyle.net, 30 Jun 2015)'), ('Coach', 'Pedro Sena [national], BRA (mainichi.jp, 10 Jan 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win gold at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia, and to finish on the podium at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (athleteyell.jp, 20 Apr 2018, 02 Mar 2018)'), ('Awards', 'In 2014 and 2015 he received the Ehime Culture and Sports Award in Japan. (ehime.jp, 2015, 26 Dec 2014)'), ('Additional Information', "GeneralSPIKING INCIDENTIn January 2018 an investigation by the Japan Canoe Federation discovered that he had been drugged by a rival at the previous year's national championships. Yasuhiro Suzuki admitted spiking Komatsu's drink with methandienone, an anabolic steroid, with the intention of causing his disqualification. At the hearing, 32-year-old Suzuki claimed he had felt under pressure from other younger athletes on the national team, and that he had hoped to increase his chances of qualifying for the 2020 Olympic Games if Komatsu tested positive for a banned substance. Komatsu's provisional suspension was lifted with immediate effect, although his results from the 2017 Japanese Championships were nullified, while Suzuki was given an eight-year ban by the Japan Anti-Doping Agency [JADA]. (kyodonews.net, 09 Jan 2018; nikkei.com, 10 Jan 2018) "), ('Hero', 'Japanese baseball player Ichiro Suzuki. (ameblo.jp, 03 Feb 2015)'), ('Languages', 'English, Japanese'), ('Hobbies', 'Skateboarding, surfing the internet. name: Satoshi
bio: [('Beginning', 'He got into athletics in middle school, and began race walking in high school. (radichubu.jp, 17 Oct 2017; nishio-rotary.org, 13 Mar 2018)'), ('Reason', 'He originally got into athletics after taking part in a marathon with his father as a child, before switching to race walking in high school. He admits that he did not like race walking in the beginning, but after surgery on his knee he grew to appreciate the discipline. "When I was not even able to walk [after surgery], I felt ashamed that I had hated race walking." (radichubu.jp, 17 Oct 2017)'), ('Coach', 'Daisuke Kodama [club], JPN; Fumio Imamura [national], JPN (jaaf.or.jp, 09 Mar 2018; this.kiji.is, 28 May 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To win medals at the 2018 Asian Games in Indonesia, the 2019 World Championships in Doha, Qatar, and the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (city.kyoto.lg.jp, 19 Oct 2017)'), ('Nickname', 'Maruchan (wakayama2015.jp, 07 Sep 2014)'), ('Injuries', 'He had surgery in order to remove part of the patella in his left knee in grade 11 of high school. name: TOMOYUKI
bio: [('Beginning', 'He first tried shooting in 1994. He began competing in 2002. (riflesports.jp, 14 Jul 2011)'), ('Reason', 'He first tried the sport when he joined the police academy. Despite not being very good to start with, he was determined to improve and decided to train harder. (jiji.com, 08 Nov 2010)'), ('Debut', '2004 for Japan, Asian Championships in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia (issf-sports.org, 2004)'), ('Coach', 'Emil Dushanov [national]; Tsunehiko Tamura [national], JPN (riflesports.jp, 02 May 2018; nikkansports.com, 31 Oct 2017)'), ('Ambition', 'To win a medal at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (sanspo.com, 19 Jul 2012; hochi.co.jp, 04 Jul 2017)'), ('Awards', 'In 2017 he was named Shooter of the Year by the International Shooting Sport Federation [ISSF]. (issf-sports.org, 24 Apr 2018)In 2017 he was given an Excellence Award at the Yokohama Sports Citation in Japan. (hamaspo.com, 19 Mar 2018)In 2011 he received the Totsuka-ku Citizen Honorary Award in Japan. (city.yokohama.jp, 21 Dec 2015) In 2010 he was given an Excellence Award at the annual Japanese Olympic Committee [JOC] Awards Ceremony. (sponichi.co.jp , 26 Apr 2011) In 2010 he received Big Sports Award at the TV Asahi Big Sports Award Ceremony in Japan. (tv-asahi.co.jp, 31 Dec 2010)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralGOLD IN ADVERSITYHe was in Ishinomaki, Japan, to compete in the national championships when the 2011 earthquake and tsunami struck the Pacific coast of the country. The hotel the shooters were staying in was destroyed and he considered withdrawing from the World Cup event in Sydney, NSW, Australia, later that month so he could be a part of the rescue team. However, he was encouraged to compete by his superiors at work in order to try and provide some good news for the country. He won two gold medals at the event and dedicated his success to the victims of the earthquake and tsunami. (pulse72plus.com, 28 Jul 2012; bbc.co.uk, 11 Apr 2012; sankei.jp.msn.com, 03 Mar 2012)TURNING POINTHe won a bronze medal at the 2005 Asian Championships in Bangkok, Thailand, in only his second international competition. He believes it was an important moment in his shooting career. "At that time I realised I could do it. It would not have been possible to progress further without that experience." (yomiuri.co.jp, 10 Jan 2012) '), ('Nickname', 'Matsuko (Facebook profile, 15 Feb 2016)'), ('Languages', 'Japanese'), ('Highlights', 'RankEventYearLocationResultAsian Games350m Pistol2010Guangzhou, bio: [('Beginning', 'He began the sport at age seven. (ntt-east.co.jp, 14 Apr 2014)'), ('Reason', 'He was influenced by his older sister. (ntt-east.co.jp, 14 Apr 2014)'), ('Debut', '2012 for Japan (smash-net.tv, 09 Mar 2014)'), ('Coach', 'Takahiro Suka [club], JPN; Park Joo-Bong [national], KOR (sankei.com, 19 Mar 2018; ntt-east.co.jp, 09 Jul 2018)'), ('Awards', 'In 2014 he was given the Mitoyo City World No.1 Honorary Award by the mayor of the city. (city.mitoyo.lg.jp, 07 Jul 2014)'), ('Additional Information', "GeneralNATIONAL FIRSTSHe became the first Japanese athlete to win a men's singles world championship medal when he claimed bronze at the 2015 World Championships in Jakarta, Indonesia. In 2015 he also became the first Japanese player to win a men's singles Super Series Final when he claimed gold at the tournament in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. (Reuters.com, 04 Dec 2017; hochi.co.jp, 02 Jun 2018; euronews.com, 08 Apr 2016)SUSPENSIONIn April 2016 he was suspended from the Japanese national team by the Nippon Badminton Association after admitting to gambling in an illegal casino in Japan. The suspension ruled him out of contention for the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. He was allowed to return to lower-level international tournaments in mid-2017, and the suspension was wholly lifted in January 2018. (Reuters.com, 04 Dec 2017; japantimes.co.jp, 12 Mar 2017; euronews.com, 08 Apr 2016) "), ('Injuries', 'In January 2018 he sprained his left ankle and required three weeks of recovery. (daily.co.jp, 12 Jan 2018)'), ('Languages', 'Japanese'), ('Hobbies', 'Listening to music, bowling. name: YOSHITAKU
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began the sport at age four. (fatbmx.com, 22 Jan 2015)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete in both track cycling and BMX at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (uci.ch, 10 Apr 2017)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralTOKYO DREAMHe has ambitions to compete in both track cycling and BMX at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. "I started track cycling when I was based at the UCI World Cycling Centre. We trained sometimes on the velodrome. I liked it and I thought I might have the potential to be a starter for the team sprint. It\'s not easy racing all year round but the playing fields are different. The people are different, the bike is different. It\'s good for me to change sometimes." (uci.ch, 10 Apr 2017; cyclingnews.com, 12 Apr 2017)MOVE ABROADHe moved from Japan to Switzerland in 2012 to train under coach Thomas Allier at the UCI World Cycling Centre in Aigle, Switzerland. In 2016 he left Switzerland and moved to California, United States of America. (fatbmx.com, 22 Jan 2015; 15.ie, 15 Mar 2016; uci.ch, 10 Apr 2017; Instagram profile, 28 Jul 2018) '), ('Hero', 'Latvian BMX rider Maris Strombergs. (Athlete, 27 Jan 2007)'), ('Nickname', 'Yoshi (uci.ch, 10 Apr 2017)'), ('Injuries', 'He underwent shoulder surgery in February 2015 after suffering from shoulder problems for several years. He returned to competition in May 2015. (cycloch.net, 09 May 2015)He missed qualification for the 2012 Olympic Games in London after fracturing his wrist one month before the Games began. name: YOSHIAKI
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began riding at about age 10. (atozinba.com, 08 Jun 2017)'), ('Reason', 'He initially got involved in equestrian sport as a hobby. "At about age 14, I started riding every day and enjoying showjumping competitions. My first time eventing was for a university competition, and we had no choice but to do all three disciplines." (eventingnation.com, 14 Jun 2017)'), ('Coach', 'Dirk Schrade, GER, from 2009 (dirk-schrade.de, 01 Dec 2017; eventingnation.com, 14 Jun 2017; Athlete, 23 Jun 2012)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete at the 2018 World Equestrian Games [WEG] in Tryon, NC, United States of America, and to win a medal at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (nikkansports.com, 10 Aug 2016; dirk-schrade.de, 15 Aug 2015)'), ('Memorable', 'Winning the 2017 Bramham Horse Trials in England. (horseandhound.co.uk, 11 Jun 2017)'), ('Awards', 'He was given the Best Athletic Award in the equestrian section at the Japanese Sports Awards in 2005, 2007 and 2011. (crane.co.jp, 14 Jan 2011; olympicfun.seesaa.net, 07 May 2008)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralLIVING ABROADHe moved to England in 2001 in order to pursue his goals in the sport, after watching the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney on television. He asked Australian Olympic gold medallist rider Andrew Hoy to coach him in 2003. Following the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing, he relocated from England to Germany. (JEF, 20 Apr 2017; Twitter profile, 06 Jul 2017; atozinba.com, 08 Jun 2017) '), ('Hero', 'Japanese showjumper Takeichi Nishi. (Athlete, 23 Jun 2012)'), ('Influence', 'Coach Dirk Schrade (Athlete, 23 Jun 2012)'), ('Relatives', 'His aunt Mieko Fujimori was a Japanese champion figure skater. name: ERI
bio: [('Beginning', 'She began cycling in 2012 when she was a university student. (sankei.com, 15 Sep 2017)'), ('Reason', 'She initially joined the tennis club at university, but she was not very good at the sport. Her uncle then suggested she should try cycling and bought her a bike. (cyclowired.jp, 18 Dec 2013)'), ('Debut', 'Turned professional in 2016'), ('Coach', 'Allan Davis [club], AUS (wigglehighfive.com, 08 Aug 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete at the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. (cyclingnews.com, 29 Jun 2016)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralROCKY ROAD TO RIOIn April 2016 she was removed from the long list of athletes eligible to compete at the Olympic Games by the Japanese Cycling Federation after she failed to follow team orders to ride for her more experienced teammate Mayuko Hagiwara at the 2016 Asian Championships in Oshima, Japan. She appealed to the Japan Sports Arbitration Agency [JSAA], which ruled in her favour the day before the road race at the 2016 Japanese Championships. She went on to win the time trial, and then beat Hagiwara into second place on the final lap of the road race to secure her place for the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. "At the beginning of this season while I was discussing my goals with my coach, we both agreed that Rio should be our number one priority. It has been a huge challenge for both of us. I have worked so hard, and I have learned so much from everyone around me. I always respect my competitors, and I appreciate everyone who made this journey possible." (cyclingnews.com, 29 Jun 2016) '), ('Relatives', 'To win a medal in the individual time trial at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (cyclist.sanspo.com, 15 Aug 2016)'), ('Education', 'School of Health and Physical Education University of Tsukuba, Japan'), ('Languages', 'English, Japanese'), ('Hobbies', 'Playing tennis. name: Masateru
bio: [('Beginning', 'He began the sport while in middle school, and took up discus in grade ten at Moriyama High School in Japan. (nikkansports.com, 24 Jun 2018)'), ('Reason', 'He wanted to play ball games, but this was not possible due to the hearing impairment he was born with. Instead he chose athletics, originally starting with sprints, hurdles and long jump before deciding to focus on discus after he showed potential in the discipline. (nikkansports.com, 24 Jun 2018; rikujyokyogi.co.jp, 15 Jul 2018)'), ('Coach', 'Kenji Tauchi [personal], JPN (mainichi.jp, 27 Jun 2018)'), ('Ambition', 'To compete at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (sports.gazoo.com, 12 Jul 2018)'), ('Additional Information', 'GeneralHEARING IMPAIRMENTHe was born with a hearing impairment, and wears a hearing device in his left ear. His parents did not want him to attend a special education school, so he did not learn to communicate by sign language. Instead, he learnt to lip read.
